title: What is Data Modeling?
content: Data modeling diagrams entities, attributes, and relationships to guide schema design and integration. It clarifies constraints and supports analytics by formalizing how data should be structured.

title: What is Data Architecture?
content: Data architecture defines standards, models, and platforms for data collection, storage, movement, and access. It ensures scalability, security, and quality while reducing duplication and silos.

title: What is Data Cleansing?
content: Data cleansing detects and fixes errors, inconsistencies, and missing values. It standardizes formats and applies validation rules to improve analytics and machine learning accuracy.

title: What is Data Preparation?
content: Data preparation converts raw inputs into analysis‑ready datasets by collecting, cleaning, enriching, labeling, and exploring. It often represents the bulk of effort in ML projects.

title: What is Data Augmentation?
content: Data augmentation creates synthetic variations of existing data—images, text, audio—to expand training sets and improve generalization for machine learning models.

title: What is Data Masking?
content: Data masking obfuscates sensitive fields via substitution, shuffling, or tokenization so realistic datasets can be used in testing or analytics without exposing secrets.

title: What is Data Backup?
content: Data backup produces recoverable copies of systems and datasets to protect against loss from failures, mistakes, or attacks, using full, incremental, or versioned strategies.

title: What is Data Sharing?
content: Data sharing makes datasets securely available to multiple apps, teams, or partners under governance. It uses access controls, contracts, and formats to maintain integrity.

title: What is a Data Catalog?
content: A data catalog inventories datasets, schemas, lineage, owners, and usage. It improves discovery and trust so users can find and reuse data consistently.

title: What is a Database?
content: A database is an organized store managed by a DBMS that provides CRUD operations, indexing, transactions, and security for structured and unstructured information.

title: What is a SQL Database?
content: A SQL database uses tables, rows, and columns with Structured Query Language to query and manipulate data. It supports relations, constraints, and ACID transactions.

title: What are NoSQL Databases?
content: NoSQL databases adopt flexible schemas and models—key‑value, document, column‑family, and graph—to scale horizontally and support diverse workloads.

title: What is a Relational Database?
content: A relational database organizes data into related tables linked by keys and supports joins to query relationships for transactional and analytical needs.

title: What is MySQL?
content: MySQL is a popular open‑source relational database known for performance and tooling. It supports replication, indexing, and SQL standards for web and product backends.

title: What is PostgreSQL?
content: PostgreSQL is an advanced open‑source relational database with strong SQL compliance, extensibility, JSON support, and rich indexing for robust, concurrent workloads.

title: What is Web Hosting?
content: Web hosting stores and serves websites and apps on internet‑connected servers. Providers manage hardware, security, backups, and scaling so teams focus on content and code.

title: What is a Web Application?
content: A web application runs in a browser and communicates with remote services, delivering interactive functionality without local installation and enabling centralized updates.

title: What is Code Quality?
content: Code quality captures reliability, readability, security, and maintainability. Adhering to standards, tests, and clear structure reduces defects and accelerates delivery.

title: What is Continuous Integration?
content: Continuous Integration frequently merges code and automatically builds and tests it to surface defects early, establish a reliable baseline, and enable rapid iteration.

title: What is Continuous Testing?
content: Continuous testing runs automated checks across the pipeline—unit, integration, end‑to‑end, performance, and security—to enforce quality gates before release.

title: What is Unit Testing?
content: Unit testing verifies small, isolated pieces of code with deterministic inputs and expected outputs, improving design and preventing regressions during change.

title: What is SDLC?
content: The software development lifecycle structures delivery from requirements through design, implementation, testing, deployment, and maintenance with governance and feedback.

title: What is ALM?
content: Application Lifecycle Management coordinates planning, development, testing, release, operations, and compliance with traceability to manage software from inception to retirement.

title: What is Version Control?
content: Version control records file changes, supports branching and merging, and enables collaborative workflows with history, rollback, and code review integration.

title: What is Git?
content: Git is a distributed VCS that stores snapshots locally and synchronizes through pushes and pulls. Its branching model supports parallel work and integrates with CI/CD.

title: What is a Repo?
content: A repository is a structured storage for source code and assets that centralizes collaboration, issues, automation, and governance for software projects.

title: What is an IDE?
content: An integrated development environment bundles editor, build tools, debugger, tests, terminals, and extensions to boost productivity and quality for developers.

title: What is an SDK?
content: A software development kit packages libraries, tools, samples, and docs to accelerate building on a platform or API, enforcing best practices and reducing boilerplate.

title: What is Infrastructure as Code?
content: Infrastructure as Code defines environments with machine‑readable files to provision, update, and roll back consistently using the same practices as application code.

title: What is DevOps?
content: DevOps unifies development and operations through automation, collaboration, CI/CD, observability, and shared ownership to deliver changes rapidly and reliably.

title: What is DevSecOps?
content: DevSecOps integrates security into every stage of delivery with automated checks—static analysis, dependency scanning, policies—and runtime monitoring as shared responsibility.

title: What is API?
content: An application programming interface is a contract of endpoints, methods, inputs, and outputs that enables predictable integration and modular system design.

title: What is a RESTful API?
content: A RESTful API applies stateless, resource‑oriented principles, standard HTTP verbs, and status codes so clients can operate on resources predictably and at scale.

title: What is MQTT?
content: MQTT is a lightweight publish‑subscribe messaging protocol for IoT devices over constrained networks. It minimizes overhead and supports device‑to‑cloud and cloud‑to‑device messaging.

title: What is ICMP?
content: ICMP communicates network diagnostics and error conditions, enabling tools like ping and traceroute to report reachability and path characteristics.

title: What is BGP?
content: Border Gateway Protocol exchanges routes between autonomous systems and selects paths based on policies and attributes to keep internet connectivity scalable and resilient.

title: What is DNS?
content: DNS maps human‑readable names to IP addresses via hierarchical zones and caching, allowing clients to locate services across networks.

title: What is DDNS?
content: Dynamic DNS automatically updates records when IP addresses change so name‑to‑address mappings remain accurate for dynamically assigned endpoints.

title: What is a VPN?
content: A virtual private network creates an encrypted tunnel over public networks to connect users or sites securely and enable remote access to private resources.

title: What is MFA?
content: Multi‑factor authentication verifies identity using multiple independent factors—knowledge, possession, or inherence—to mitigate credential theft beyond passwords.

title: What is SSO?
content: Single Sign‑On lets users access multiple applications after one authentication, improving experience and centralizing access policies and auditing.

title: What is 5G?
content: 5G is the fifth generation cellular network offering higher throughput, lower latency, and greater capacity than 4G, enabling advanced applications like AR, IoT, and autonomous systems.

title: What is a Data Center?
content: A data center is a physical facility housing servers, storage, networking, and supporting infrastructure. It provides power, cooling, security, and connectivity for hosting digital systems.
